docs.lead_paragraph: With generics accounting for 70 percent of all drugs on the market, their ever-changing appearances affects almost anyone who fills a prescription.

headline.seo: A Kaleidoscope of Generics Puts Patients to the Test

docs.lead_paragraph: A cheap deworming pill used in Africa for 25 years against river blindness was recently shown to kill mosquitoes when they bite people who have recently swallowed the drug.

headline.seo: Worm Drug Ivermectin Is Shown to Kill Mosquitoes
headline.main: Human Swallows Pill. Mosquito Bites Human. Mosquito Dies.
headline.print_headline: Human Swallows Pill. Mosquito Bites Human. Mosquito Dies.

docs.snippet: A cheap deworming pill used in Africa for 25 years against river blindness was recently shown to kill mosquitoes when they bite people who have recently swallowed the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: This year, a Seattle nurse named Kim Hiatt committed suicide. Ms. Hiatt's death came nearly seven months after she had given an unintended overdose to an infant heart patient, a medical error that was said to have contributed to the child's death days later. Ms. Hiatt had been a nurse for 27 years and had often cared for the 8-month-old girl during the child's stay in the pediatric intensive care unit of her hospital. She had probably drawn up the right dose of the drug hundreds of times in her career. But once, she made a life-changing error. A baby died, and she was suspended, then fired from a profession she loved. And now she's dead. This story makes me feel sick -- sick for that dead baby and her parents, and sick for Kim, who must have felt so alone with her pain.

headline.main: Big or Small, Nurses' Mistakes Reverberate

docs.abstract: Theresa Brown essay on experience of making medical errors as a nurse, and what it can be like to have to live with the knowledge and consequences of a failure in patient care; drawing (M)
